section.heading: Argument of Robert A. Long, Jr.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Samson versus California.
Mr. Long.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court--
The search in this case was not based on individualized suspicion, and no other adequate safeguards limited the police officer's discretion to search Petitioner.
For this reason, the search, which would not be permitted by virtually any other State or by the Federal Government, was unreasonable.
The Court has reaffirmed many times that the fourth amendment does not permit the individual officer in the field to exercise unconstrained discretion to search.

The Court has said that the fourth amendment is primarily directed at the evil... it was primarily directed at the evil of general warrants and writs of assistance, and the evil of general warrants and writs of assistance was that they gave individual officers blanket authority to search where they pleased and placed the liberty of every man in the hands of every petty officer.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Long--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Long--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --with respect to liberty, as it... it's not disputed, is it, that your client could have had his parole revoked even though the search was suspicionless?
So, we're talking about the difference between revocation of parole, on the one hand, and a separate criminal offense.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, a parolee has conditional liberty.
But, at the time of this search, Mr. Samson was on parole, there was no suspicion of any wrongdoing--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But I thought that evidence seized could be introduced, could be a basis to revoke parole.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Oh, well, the Court held, in the Scott case, that the exclusionary rule does not apply at parole revocation hearings.
So, if there is an unreasonable search of a parolee that violates the fourth amendment, the evidence could not be admitted at a criminal trial, but it could be admitted at a parole revocation--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So, the... what the... the consequence here is whether--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --he will have his parole revoked--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --or he will have a separate criminal offense.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I understand your question.
In California, Justice Ginsburg, a nonviolent drug offense, the possession of a small amount of an illegal substance, is not a basis for revocation of parole.
It is not possible to revoke parole in California for this offense.
So, parole revocation would not have been a possibility here.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, Justice Ginsburg, I suppose, can pursue her own line of questioning, but let me ask you this, because I... her question suggests this, to me at least.
Suppose the parole officer said,
"Now, look, I'm going to search you. "
"If you don't consent, then I'm going to revoke your parole. "

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, this, of course, was a police officer, not a parole officer.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: But if--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Well, I... my question was a parole officer, and I'll get to police officer next.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --All right.
I think if a parole officer said,
"You must consent to this search-- "

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: When you see the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --"# this particular search"--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --person on the street, et cetera, et cetera.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: "And, if you don't, I'll revoke your. "
--I mean, the consent is not, in this case, first.
I mean, California has said, the Supreme Court has said, parole, in the parole search condition, is imposed as a matter of law.
Your hypothetical poses a question of, Could there be knowing and voluntary consent to a search if the consequence of refusing is revocation of parole?
I would argue, in that situation, that the consequences of refusal are so dire that, effectively, the parolee would have no real choice but to consent.
So, it would be, in a sense, a coerced consent.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why are they dire?
I mean, he's just back in the situation he would have been in, did he not comply with the conditions of his parole.
I don't see that that's dire.
He has a choice.
He can stay in prison and--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --and suffer the reduction of privacy there, which is much, much greater than being subjected to... I mean, he... he cannot even go to the toilet in privacy.
Or he can go out on parole, subject to the condition that--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that he--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I mean--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --he can--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --be searched.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I have two answers to that, Justice Scalia.
I mean, first, in California, you finish your prison sentence, and then parole is a separate period that happens.
The California Supreme Court said, in People v. Guzman and other cases, parole is not a part of the sentence--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, but it's--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --in California.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --but it's also clear from the California statute that it is not a right, that it's a privilege, that you get the privilege of parole in exchange... in exchange for agreeing to the conditions, one of which is that you can be searched.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's... in California, every inmate gets parole.
It's a matter of law.
It's not a privilege... in Morrissey against Brewer.
The Court... in other cases, the Court rejected the rights privilege distinction anyway.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: California statute says it's a privilege, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, in Section 3067.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It does.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: But it is... it is also a... Section 3000 of the California penal code says every prisoner gets parole.
It is imposed on the prisoner as--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Even if the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --a matter of law.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --prisoner... oh, I thought that he can turn it down, and that some prisoners do, if--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --if they decide that they don't want to be subjected to searches.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --The California Supreme Court has held, in People v. Reyes, and in other cases cited in our brief, that, in California, parole is not a matter of choice, it is imposed as a matter of law.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is... and you mean people are put out on the street when... kicking and screaming when they say,
"No, I want to stay in jail. "
"I don't want to be-- "

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: "# searched. "
"I would rather stay in jail? "
And--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --they are dragged out--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --That--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --into the street.
Is that what happens?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --That is what the California Supreme Court has said.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, I--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: And what the statutes say is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I don't think so.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --That... the statutes say that parole is a... is a transitional period, and that every inmate should undergo a period of parole.
But coming back to your earlier question, the Court has said that the condition of a parolee is very different from the condition of a prisoner.
The Court said that in Morrissey against Brewer.
And the Court said, in Griffin, as to probationers, that while the fourth amendment rights of probationers... and so, parolees, too, we concede... are reduced, there are... the State can go too far.
And if the State exceeds--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, but--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --the permissible limits, it's a violation.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --their condition is very different, in a broad range of areas.
They... you give up first amendment rights.
For example, it's typical to have a condition of parole that you don't consort with known criminals or gang members.
You... often it says you must refrain from alcohol.
Sometimes they say you can't go near particular places, if they think that's going to tempt you to return to a life of crime.
Those are all first amendment rights that are sacrificed while you're on parole.
Why is this any different?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there are many rights that are sacrificed.
What the Court has said about the fourth amendment rights is, because parolees have conditional liberty, they will have a reduced, but not eliminated, fourth amendment protection--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What about a drug... what if you're convicted of a drug offense, you're on parole, and one of the conditions is, every week you have to go in for a drug test?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, that--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Do you--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --that would be--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --do you... is that acceptable?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --That would be different in several respects, Mr. Chief Justice.
First of all, there would not be discretion.
You wouldn't have the individual officer--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But it would be a fourth amendment right that you would be giving up--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes.
And--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --that you would otherwise have if you weren't on parole.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --And I want to be clear, we are not... we're arguing there is a broad spectrum of searches that States can undertake of parolees, and I'm, by no means, arguing today that all of them, or even most of them, are unconstitutional.
This is a--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What would you say about a condition that you must... not a regular drug test... you just have to submit yourself to a drug test whenever a police officer asks you to?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, you know, that would be much narrower, because it would simply be a drug test.
I think it would have the problems of... the officer would have complete discretion.
If it were like the California--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, but it's... I mean, the point--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think it would valid?
That's what I was asking you.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I think, because that's a much narrower test, that that could pass muster if... but I would think there really ought to be some guidance to the officer.
I think our ultimate submission today is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, so that a--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --this is so--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --so that a burglar could be searched for burglar tools--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --but not for drugs?
And the drug addict can be searched for drugs, and not burglar tools?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --If it were... if it were tied to the crime that the parolee has committed, you know, that would give it some limitation.
This is a completely unlimited search, for anything, any crime.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --But Justice Stevens's question highlights the point that you criticize about, the randomness of it is often a critical element.

I suppose it makes much more sense to say you're subject to a random drug test than that you have to come in at a scheduled time, when you... presumably, you could refrain from using drugs prior to the test.
And, to some extent, it's the same, even if you're not talking about a drug test.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in all--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: The search is only going to be effective if it's not announced or--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, in--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --scheduled.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --and in this Court's suspicionless search cases, you can have a random test where you draw names at random.
There's some other process that doesn't leave it up to each individual officer to decide who gets the drug test or which car to stop to check the driver's license and registration.
What the Court has consistently held as really at the core of the fourth amendment is this notion of the individual officer in the field has complete discretion to decide,
"Do I search this person? "
"Do I not? "
"What's the scope of the search? "
"What do-- "

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Are you relying--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --"# I search for"?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --on the difference between... you said "officer in the field".
Would this be okay if it had been his parole officer?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The parole officer was walking along the street, saw this guy, and said, "I'm going to search you".

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I think it's a very different set of circumstances if we have a parole officer.
This Court has said, at least twice, in Griffin and in Scott, that a parole officer has a different function.
They are not in an adversarial, or a purely adversarial, relationship.
They often think of the parolee or the probationer as a client.
They're trying to see that the person succeeds.
In some sense, the parole officer fails when the parolee goes back to prison.
The parole... the parole officer can act on their entire knowledge and experience with the client, or the parolee.
So, all of that makes a difference.
And the Court has noted that several times.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When he's in prison, is there any problem about the prison guards intruding upon his privacy, willy nilly, whenever they choose?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: The... as I understand the Court's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, walking--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --holding--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --by his cell, which is always opened, and checking in on him to see what's... what he's doing.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --As I understand the Court's holding in Hudson against Palmer, the fourth amendment does not apply in a prison cell.
And--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So, he's better off on parole than... well, at least no worse off on parole than he would be when he was in prison.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --But, Your Honor, that's not the way this Court has analyzed the fourth amendment issues.
It's a different situation.
It is conditional liberty.
It's the... that sort of active grace theory, or right, privilege, distinction, or greater power includes the lesser, all those arguments have been rejected, in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Are--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Morrissey against Brewer, and Gagnon--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --against Scarpelli.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Not--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --what do you make of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --by me.
No, go ahead.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: It's--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --I was going to say, What do you make of the pragmatic argument that seems to cut all of your objections?

The pragmatic argument is both in favor of complete discretion and of suspicionless search, that the in terrorem effect of knowing that these searches can occur at any moment, in fact, discourages recidivism.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What's your response to that?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I have a pragmatic argument, and then I have an argument just based on the fourth amendment.
Pragmatically, no other State, as far as we can tell, and not the Federal Government, authorizes this kind of search; that is, blanket suspicionless discretionary searches by police officers.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Apart from--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: So--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Apart from the lack of popularity of the State's view, do--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --do we have... do we have any empirical evidence that bears on the in terrorem argument?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --The... well, the empirical evidence is that all the other States don't seem to be having a harder time--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --with recidivism.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --I realize that.
But, beyond that, do we have any empirical evidence, one way or the other?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the California... I think that's a pretty powerful demonstration, but we do have, beyond that, empirically, California was with all the other States until the People against Reyes decision.
Now they've moved to suspicionless searches.
They seem to have about the same rate of recidivism--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I take it--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --as they--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --the answer is--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --did before.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --we don't have any empirical evidence, one way or the other, apart from the fact that California stands out in its system.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I... I'm... think I'm offering you evidence that counts as empirical in my mind, but--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --apparently it's not--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --I know it, but I've said, about three times, that I want to get beyond the peculiar position of California to any other empirical evidence that cuts for you or against you.
And I take it there really isn't--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, there... we have a footnote.
There is a brief submitted by a Stanford law professor, and we have at least a footnote in our brief.
There is some social science research that suggests that this more intensive supervision is really not effective, if you look at broad numbers.
I mean, I think you will catch some additional people.
I mean, it happened in this case.
But if you step back and look at the overall effects, it's not... it's not particularly helpful--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Why, if we're going to catch some additional people, is that not sufficient?
That is, why is it unreasonable, say, not for law professors, but business school professors, management consultants, to say,

"You have a lot of prisoners in California, hundreds of thousands... I don't know, maybe more than 100,000... and we'll tell the Legislature that they can cut the terms, save money, release them early, but we want to have management checks. "
"And the management checks are, you might be searched at any time. "
"And we catch a few. "
"And that's helpful. "
Now, if the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --State decides that, what's unreasonable about it?
"They're"--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: "# letting the people out earlier than they otherwise would-- "

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Because--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --says the Legislature.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Because, Justice Breyer, it has to be a balancing analysis, and--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And what's on the other side?
The other side--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --is, you'd rather not have policemen search you, but your alternative is going to be in jail.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, I mean, the other side is a search condition that says you have... you could be searched at any time, any place, by any police officer for evidence of any crime, is a breathtakingly broad invasion of privacy.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But, of course, that's how it happens when he's in prison.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, but he has come out of prison.
The State has seen fit to release him on parole into society.
He has conditional liberty.
And the Court--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But there is a breathtakingly high probability that he is committing a crime.

The statistics cited in the Government's brief say that in an April 2001 report prepared by the California Criminal Justice Statistics Center, 68 percent of adult parolees are returned to prison... 68 percent; 55 percent, for a parole violation; and 13 percent for the commission of a new felony offense.
I mean, it seems to me a breathtaking statistic like that may call for breathtaking--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --measures to try to police the matter closely.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: It is a very serious problem.
We don't want to minimize it.
I mean, it is a fact that many... many parolees... and this is true especially in California... end up being returned for technical violations, like not showing up to meetings with parole officers.
Some of the offenses are not as serious as others.
But it is a very serious problem.
We recognize that.
But what the Court has said is that the gravity of the problem cannot justify any means.
There has to be a balancing of the invasion of privacy against the State's need to undertake this.
And coming back to my second answer to the question you asked several minutes ago, Justice Scalia, I mean, ultimately this search is a... it's a general warrant.
It's a writ of assistance.

It's limited to parolees, but if the Court is going to stand by what it has said in Griffin and other cases, that their parolees and probationers have some modicum of fourth amendment rights... reduced, we recognize that... this is... this is the core of what the--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --framers of--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --California--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --the fourth amendment prohibited.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --The California Supreme Court said that the fourth amendment applied to these searches, but it only protected in a limited way, along the same lines as we said in Griffin.
And the standard they applied was, it protected against arbitrary or harassing or capricious searches--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --which seems to go to your argument, which is centered around the unbridled discretion of the officer.
And the California Supreme Court is saying it's not unbridled.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --That is their answer to my argument, and I want to be very clear about
"arbitrary, capricious, and harassing. "
That's the California Supreme Court's standard.
So, of course, they get to define it.
And they have not defined it the way this Court perhaps would define "arbitrary".
It's not arbitrary, capricious, or harassing if it has a permissible law enforcement purpose.
So, as long as the officer says,
"Well, I don't have any reason to think there's evidence of any crime here, but that's what I'm looking for. "
"Perhaps there's evidence of crime-- "

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --that's enough.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --fine.
But it turns out he stops the guy every hour of the day, then he has a pretty strong case that this is for harassment, and it's not--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --for the special law enforcement--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, and--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --need that accompanies releasing parolees.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --And I take it the fourth amendment itself would prohibit that sort of thing.
But it... you couldn't... you couldn't justify a general warrant by saying,
"Well, yes, the officer can search anybody, without any suspicion, and he can choose. "
But it... you know, the search can't happen too often, or it can't last too long.
That would not be... and you... and you... similarly, it would not be an answer to say,
"Well, as long as he's looking for evidence of crime. "

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: No, but your point was that this is the core of the fourth amendment, and they're taking away all of the protection and leaving it to the unbridled discretion.
And that turns out to be not the case.
Under the law that authorizes the procedure, the California Supreme Court interpretation is that the fourth amendment provides protection against harassment or arbitrary and--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --capricious searches.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I mean, my argument is that what is left of the fourth amendment under the California approach is not the core.
It's the far periphery.
There has never been a case... and we were able to find over a hundred, and perhaps over 200; it depends on how you count... of cases where parolees or probationers have said,
"You know, this search was arbitrary or capricious or harassing. "
It is always rejected, for the same reason it was in this case.
The Court says, "Well"--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Then which way do you think that cuts?
There's--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --never been a case of a harassing search of a parolee.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I mean, that's what... or 200 cases in the--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I think it cuts in the direction that it is an empty, vacuous standard.
It's a standard--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --that's always--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Why?
If it... if it... if it... it doesn't go to the suspicionless character of the search, but it does say it has to be reasonable in time, place, or manner.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And maybe the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --officers are reasonable in time, place--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --or manner.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: And... but it's... it had... there has never been a case in which a court has rejected a parolee search as unreasonable in time, place, or manner.
And you could--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: How many times has it been challenged--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --on the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --we said--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --on the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --at... we found over a hundred cases in which it's been challenged in the California courts.
And it--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

section.heading: Rebuttal of Robert A. Long, Jr.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I mean, if you think about it, if the search is, say, at night, the argument is going to be... well, if we said we'd not...
"never going to search you at night. "
then you would commit crimes at night.
We had a very extreme case in our brief about body cavity searches.
And they said,
"Well, that... of course, that. "
--you know, the suggestion was,
"Of course, that would be too extreme. "
But you could see an argument if parolees and probationers knew that that was off limits, that... you know, that would become a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You say there was a case in which, without any special reason, they did--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --No.
Let--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --a cavity--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And that would--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Let me be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Oh, okay.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I am not aware of any actual case.
We posited that.
We said... you know, because you don't need to know anything about the parolee, except he's on parole, and you can search for evidence of any crime.
You don't need any suspicion that... so, you could have somebody, a sort of white collar criminal, or you'd check someone who's written a bad check.
And if you say,
"Well, I think perhaps you're involved in drugs. "
"Maybe you're one of these balloon swallowers. "
--you don't need any actual reason to think that's happening, you can simply say, "I want to investigate that".
And the way... you have to investigate by X rays or something else quite intrusive.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The California Supreme Court may... might well hold that it's arbitrary to conduct such an extreme search as a body cavity search, or to... I don't know--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --to decide to search the person when he's in the men's room or something.
I mean, there are--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --there are a lot of limitations that the California court--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --They might, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --could put on it, within the context of harassment or--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --But our principal submission, Justice Scalia... I mean, if California said,
"We have a terrible problem with crime in California; and, therefore, we're authorizing every police officer to search every person anytime, anywhere, for any crime. "
that would be, I would submit, the clearest sort of fourth amendment violation you could imagine.
It would be a general warrant or a writ of assistance.
It couldn't possibly be justified by saying,
"Well, if it gets too extreme, if it gets into body cavity searches, we won't allow it. "
We are talking about parolees, yes.
Their fourth amendment rights are reduced, yes.
We recognize that.
But saying that this sort of absolutely unguided discretion--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But the reason--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --there's no sort of--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --the reason that people, I think, are saying that is because they have a lot of prisoners, they're trying to create a category of people who don't have to stay in prison, where they have no rights.
And the real question is, Can California, in trying to create this interim category, reduce the fourth amendment right in the way you describe?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --They--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Of course they can't do it, but the justification is not that there is something bad about this particular individual or he's in some kind of limbo.
The reason is that there's a policy tending towards release, which California has decided they want to introduce this as a condition.
Now--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --and so, what... and the question is, What's unreasonable about that?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what's unreasonable about it is that it goes so far in the direction of eliminating the fourth amendment rights of people who are not prisoners... they are... they have conditional liberty... that it is simply not consistent with the fourth amendment.
And on the empirical side, California is an outlier.
All the other States--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I... may I ask you--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --and the Federal Government--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --this question?
Part of your appeal of your case is, you talk about the corporate offender or tax dodger, something like that.
It seems quite unreasonable, I agree with you.

But what if you defined the class much more narrowly and limit it to people who have been convicted of violent crimes of a very serious nature and so forth, and said, as to those, they can have the totally suspicionless search?
Would that--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --be possible?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I... one of the things we wanted to make... I think there are many things that States can do.
They could certainly--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But I wonder whether--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --there's the possibility of--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --whether you think they could do that.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --There's the possibility of individual determinations, based on the individual circumstances.
If you went--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what I'm--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --category by--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --I want to see if there is a way that the class could be defined narrowly, because I want to ask the other side if they would allow the search for any ex felon, for example.
You could write it in a way that seemed obviously too broad.
But is--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --there a narrower class--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --that you think would be acceptable?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I think this could be much narrower.
And, in my view, it would become a much closer constitutional question if it were limited to certain crimes where the legislature or the State made a finding that there's a particular need to have--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Say you were a--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --suspicionless--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --terrorist, for example.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --And--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Just limit it to terrorists, convicted terrorists.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes, perhaps convicted terrorists.
You know, that... and it... that's very different from what we have here, because--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --What about drug offenders, given the high rate of recidivism?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, I... you know, we... I think you would have to see the facts of that case, but if they made a finding that,
"Because of the nature of drug offenses, we need suspicionless searches rather than simply reasonable suspicion, and we need police officers, not parole officers. "
--and there could be other regulations.
The Federal regulations, we think, are a model, really.
They have lots of limitations on--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Mr. Long, is it... is it fair to compare California to other States?
The assumption would have to be that other States grant parole as liberally as California does.
Maybe California has made the decision,
"We have too many people in prison. "
"We're going to let a lot of them out, but we're going to keep them on a very tight leash. "
Why shouldn't it be able to do that +/?
to have tighter controls, but let out many more people on parole, which is... which is exactly what I think they're doing.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, and I... I think they can have tighter controls, Your Honor.
They can... they can have... they could have... they could make this a special condition of parole--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But my only--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --rather than a general condition--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --point is--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --of parole.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --the fact that other States aren't as tight doesn't prove anything, because other States--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --may not be--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --be trying to do the same thing--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --I mean--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --to empty their prisons--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --This Court has said, generally, that what the Court has found to be reasonable for one State is reasonable for all.
And when a practice is not well established... and here, it's far from well established; California's virtually unique... the Court has taken that into account for--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Suppose you were in a halfway house, and the State says,
"We're creating a status. "
"One is, you're a prisoner. "
"Another is, you're a halfway house. "
"Another is, on your... parole. "
"But we want to subject you to suspicionless searches at... in all three stages... prison, halfway house, parole. "
Could they do it for the halfway house?

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, they might... halfway houses, as I understand it, Justice Ginsburg, are largely now a thing of the past.
But if the idea is you would actually be in a custody situation at night, perhaps in lockdown, then perhaps Hudson against Palmer would come into play--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: This person goes--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --which--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --out to work, comes back at the end of the day, and is checked in.

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --And so, your hypothetical is, Could there be suspicionless searches by--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yeah, while the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --police officers--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --while the--

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --at work?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --The person who is in this semi custody state, he's going to work, and, while he's at his workplace, the police officer shows up and says,
"I'm going to pat you down, and then I'm going to-- "

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: It's--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: "# see if you have drugs. "

turn.speaker: robert_a_long_jr
turn.label: Mr. Robert A. Long, Jr.
turn.text: --It's a... it's a harder case.
Again, our bottom line is, there would need to be some limitations on that individual officer's discretion.
That's the core of the fourth amendment.
If there are no further questions, I'd like to reserve the balance of my time.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Long.
Mr. Niver, we'll hear now from you.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it... may it please the Court--

Alarmed by the State rate of recidivism and revocation of the more than 100,000 parolees, California enacted a statute which authorized the search of a parolee based solely on his status as a parolee.
We submit that such a search is reasonable under the fourth amendment.
As this Court held recently in United States versus Knights, to determine the validity of the search we balance the State's need to search against the privacy interest affected.
Here, the need is overwhelming, and the privacy interest is dramatically reduced.
Turning first to Petitioner's expectation of privacy, it is greatly diminished.
Even if it exists, it is far less than that enjoyed by the average law abiding citizen.
No one outside the confines of a prison has a lesser expectation of privacy than a parolee.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why is that?
Doesn't that kind of beg the question?
I mean, if we say he's got the normal fourth amendment rights, his... I mean, the expectation of privacy analysis seems to me to be totally circular.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: That's what the--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: You say he doesn't have an expectation of privacy, so it's not protected.
Well, if we say he does have a... if we say it is protected, then he does have an expectation of privacy.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Well, this Court spoke to that in Knights and said, unanimously that the... in Knights, it was a probation condition, but I think that it... obviously, the same analysis applies here... that the imposition or acceptance of a... of a search condition by a parolee or a probationer results in the severely diminished expectation of privacy enjoyed by the parolee or probationer.
And this Court said that unanimously in Knights.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Knights involved a situation where reasonable suspicion was required, so it addressed the problem that Mr. Long has of unbridled discretion.
You still had to have an articulable reasonable suspicion with respect to the individual.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor, but the threshold question was whether he had an expectation of privacy at all, or to the... the extent of that expectation of privacy.
And the Court, in Knights, before it discussed the balance, had to identify the factors in the balance.
In terms of the probationer's interest in that case, by virtue of the search condition, this Court said that his interest in... his expectation of privacy was severely diminished, and left open--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why... and why was his expectation of privacy severely diminished?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Because of the parole's... excuse me... the probation search that was imposed upon him by virtue of the--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Because of the very practice that's being challenged here today, right?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Well, yes.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Because he saw something... you... he signed something that said, "You're subject to searches".
Well, that's what is at issue.
It seems to me that it's... I guess I've said it before, he's... it's begging the question to say,
"You can do this, because he has a diminished expectation of privacy. "
How far do you push this?
Can you have parolees come in and take a lie detector test every week?
Do they have... do they have diminished expectation with respect to their fifth amendment rights?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: With regard to the fifth amendment rights, if they are not in custody, then... or even if they are... I don't think that that would necessarily... the... any expectation of privacy would preclude the imposition of a lie detector test, no.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Was that a yes, you can have them--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --You can.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Yes.
But in this case, the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What about--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --What about--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Is that right?
I mean, even in prison, I... what... I'm not sure you could even do that if they were still in prison.
Can you subject people in prison--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Well, of course, that would not be a fourth amendment claim.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --No.
No, I--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: It would be a different--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --The Chief Justice was trying to get out of the fourth amendment into the fifth.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --That failing... well, in terms of the lack of a precedent from this Court, you know, at this point we can only speculate, but it seems to me that if a person can be required to submit to a drug test by virtue of the status as a parolee or probationer, I don't think that it is an extravagant step to say that they could be required to submit to an--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you say the same thing if the offense he had committed was tax evasion or price fixing or speeding?
Would the... would a person on parole for any one of those offenses have... be subject to the same risk of a suspicionless search?
And would it be justified?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Suspicionless search?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Where we're back to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --applying this statute to--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --a price fixer, tax evader, speeder.
Do you think it's justified?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: If he's on parole, Your Honor, if he's... look, this applies to parolees in California who have been convicted of felonies, served time in prison, and have been--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And if it's to be--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --released on parole.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --applied to the tax offender and so forth, how about just applying it to all ex felons?
Would that be permissible?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: On parole, or not on--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, just the very fact that there's... they're an ex felon.
And let the person know, at the time of his discharge from prison, that,
"This is one of the things that the State is going to exact from you as punishment for your crime. "

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --If the person is on parole, the answer--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I'm saying--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --he's not on parole.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --he's no longer on parole?
Than the entire balance changes.
The reduction of the expectation of privacy--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But I'm hypothesizing a case in which the law will destroy the expectation of privacy, because it will provide that all ex felons are subject to search.
So, they would know, the same as a parolee now knows, he's subject to search.
Would that be valid?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --My answer to that is, it would not be valid, Your Honor, because a person, having served his time on parole, the State's overwhelming interest in supervision has ended.
The State has determined that that person, having successfully completed his period of parole--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But... so you don't--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Most--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --rely on--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Most States--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --the fact that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --don't let felons vote.
I mean, that's a punishment that they impose after they're out of prison.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Yes, but this is not... yes, Your Honor, but this is really not about punishment, this is about supervision.
And if a parolee has successfully completed this parole, has been discharged from parole, then the balance--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But then we're not relying on the elimination of the expectation of privacy, because, under my hypothetical statute, the ex felon would know he's subject to it.
So, it has to be something other than the absence of an expectation of privacy.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Not... a person who is no longer on parole, there is no longer the overwhelming State interest in supervision.
The balance changes.
Our position would be that that would not be a permissible search.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It seems to me that the principal difference, Mr. Niver, is that when he's on parole, it's in lieu of being in jail.
If that's not the difference, you don't persuade me.
He has voluntarily accepted the parole in exchange for his getting out of jail.
And he'd be in worse condition if he were in jail.
That's what, seems to me, makes the difference.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Well, that's... I think that's exactly right, Your Honor.

The ex parolee, no longer on parole, is no longer in custody of the... of the California Department of Corrections, there is no longer an overwhelming need to supervise the person, who, having successfully completed parole, is presumptively not the threat to society that he was that he... when he was a parolee.
The balance changes, and such a condition... that is to say a suspicionless search of an ex parolee... I think would offend the fourth amendment.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Niver--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But what do you achieve by this system that you have that you couldn't achieve by a system that more carefully worked out the rules and conditions of a random search?
I mean, rules, so that you avoid the totally discretionary element.
And if you want to have management consultants, as I was imagining, have 'em.
They're not just going to tell you,
"Go and ask anybody to search anytime he wants. "
They'll have a system worked out.
So, why not at least require you to think it through that much?
And, otherwise, it is unreasonable.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Well, we have disputed Petitioner's position that this is a search, although suspicionless, that it is... that discretion is not circumscribed is our position.
And it is, because--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Well, are there manuals... are there any... here is the cop on the beat.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: He sees someone that he knows is a parolee.
Is there any instruction that he's been given so that his discretion can be guided instead of rudderless?
In practice in California, are all--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: In... I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Yes.
What is the practice?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: In practice, the... a search... a parole search may not be arbitrary, capricious, or conducted solely for the purpose of harassing--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I'm asking you about what instruction, what training, if you know, are officers given?
Or are they given no training, just the law that says, "You can search any parolee"?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --No, they are not told that they may search any parolee, Your Honor.
Rather, they are told that the search must be to rehabilitate, reform, or have some other law enforcement purpose.
And they--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
The officer says,
"I'm searching to see whether the person has any evidence of crime on him. "
For example, whether he has any drugs on him.
Law enforcement purpose, supervisory, I suppose.
They want to know whether their... whether their parolees are committing offenses.
And yet, that reason would apply to everyone virtually all the time.
So, it doesn't seem to be a limitation at all.
What... am I... am I missing something?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --It does apply... it is a limitation.
It is not a limitation that would protect the expectation of privacy of a nonparole--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, how does the limitation work?
The guy is on 1st Street, and an officer says, you know,
"I recognize this person is a parolee, and I have a law enforcement objective. "
"Is the person committing a crime? "
"Is the... is the person a recidivist? "
"Is the person violating parole? "
So, he searches him.
The person gets to 2nd Street, another officer does the same thing.
Three hours later, a third officer does the same thing.
In each case, it seems to me, their justification would not fall afoul of the arbitrary, capricious, or harassment standard.
It's not coordinated.
They have a... both a parole and a law enforcement objective.
Why is there any limitation, then, on the right to search?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --If these are, as I understand Your Honor's hypothetical, three independent searches--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Uh huh.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --to the extent that that could happen, and I suppose it could, the... again, the limitation is that it be, as Your Honor states, for a valid law enforcement purpose, and it would require--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No.
No, but let's get behind the rhetoric.
Is there any reason my hypothetical could not, in fact, turn out to be true?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --There is no--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Apart from the unlikelihood of all those police officers out there.
But, leaving that aside, is there... is there any reason, in the standard, that my hypothetical could not be true?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, no, there is no reason, but it would... it requires more than testimony by the officers.

If the officers at... each testified that they conducted the search, they're... also requires a finding of fact by the trial court that the searches were, in fact, for a valid law enforcement purpose.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
I mean, let's assume the police are telling the truth, and the judge says, "Sure".
So, there is no limitation.
And it sounds to me, then, as though about the only limitation that would be enforceable would be the limitation against harassment.
If one officer did it every 15 minutes to the same person, or if there were a departmental systematic policy saying, you know, "Get so and so", that I can understand as being a limitation.
But I don't see any other limit.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Well, the limitation is, as Your Honor states, if it's a... for a valid law enforcement purpose or to promote rehabilitation or--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I realize--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --recommend--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --but do you--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --do you agree that there is not any practical limitation, other than the harassment limitation?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --I... well, that harassment limitation is sufficient to protect the residuum of an expectation--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, maybe--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --maybe it is.
But what's the answer to my question?
Is that, in practical terms, the only limitation?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --It is a... but it... yes, Your Honor, that is the protection.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought you said that maybe cavity searches would not... would not be allowed without some special reason for them.
And that wouldn't necessarily be harassment.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: I think it depends on the circumstances of the search.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: There's an--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I mean--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --overarching principle here, under the fourth amendment, that the search be reasonable, in terms of manner and scope.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: That applies equally to a suspicionless search as it would to a search based on individual suspicion.
To that extent, it's really not an issue that arises from the fact that this is suspicionless.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What would be arbitrary and capricious?
You told us harassing would be the repeated searches by the same officer.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Or an--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What--

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Or a needlessly intrusive search, as has been just described, or--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, let's assume... let's assume that the cavity search is demanded at the bus station, and the officer says,
"We know that drugs get transported by people who ingest them in the balloons, and they get on buses and they travel back and forth from city A to city B.. "
Any reason that that would run afoul of arbitrary and capricious?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Depends on the circumstances of the search.
Again, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All I'm telling you is, he's at a bus station.
The facts are that a lot of people who travel on buses are drug couriers.
This person is a parolee.
Would that run afoul of the... of any arbitrary and capricious limitation?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --It would, for example, if it were done in public view.
If the officer didn't, then--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, sure, but the officer says,
"All right. "
"I'm taking you down to the station for a cavity search. "

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --Again, the office... if the officer did it under those circumstances, it's for the finder of fact to decide whether it was done for a legitimate purpose or--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, you're... I'm asking you to be the finder of fact for me.
This is the officer's explanation.
This is the factual... set of factual premises on which he acts.
Has he violated the arbitrary and capricious limitation?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --If, in fact, it was for the purpose that you state, a legitimate law enforcement purpose, and he has been removed from public view, and it's reasonable, in terms of manner and intensity, then it would be permissible.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I have one--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, suppose you couldn't--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --I have one--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --you couldn't--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --I have--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --conduct cavity searches without some special reason, even in prison.
Wouldn't that be... isn't there some remnant of a fourth amendment right in prison that you cannot subject, you know, the whole cellblock to cavity searches?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: That would depend, Your Honor, on the prison, the prison regs, the State.
I can't answer that question--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, I--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --I thought the assumption of your answer to my question a moment ago was that there was no such limitation, so far as California is concerned.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --No, there is a limitation, in terms of manner and scope.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, sure.
But we... the manner, in this case, is, they take him down to the station, so that they're not going through this in the middle of a crowded bus terminal.
But the point of the question was, any parolee at a bus terminal could be subjected to this demand for search, and I thought your answer was, yes, he could be.
And now, in response to Justice Scalia's question, you're saying,
"Well, there may be some limitation. "
So, which is it?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: That if the search is a... for a valid law enforcement purpose, and it is reasonable in scope and manner, then it is a permissible parolee search, in California.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Does it depend... I mean, what if he's on parole for transporting drugs in balloons from bus stations?
Does that make a difference +/?
as opposed to, he's on parole for tax fraud.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: It certainly might, Your Honor.
And, again, that would be... that... an additional bit of evidence to present... to be presented to the suppression court to determine whether the scope of the search was reasonable.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But all this is on a case... would be on a case by case basis.
There are no going in guides for the officer on the street.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: It's necessarily determined on the... any search has to be decided... the reasonableness of any search has to be decided on a case by case basis.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do we--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But the reasonableness here would be unreasonable, unless there are some checks.
We're talking about suspicionless searches.
And you could have checks.
But what about saying... why is it reasonable to do it without any rule based controls on the behavior of the police?
That's the question.

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: Okay.
And the answer is, in terms of the competing interests, the lowered expectations--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

But what interest does it serve not to have some rules, manuals, regulations that help make sure it really is random, or help make sure it isn't harassing, or help make sure that it's serving the very ends that you hope to serve with the suspicionless searches?

turn.speaker: ronald_e_niver
turn.label: Mr. Ronald E. Niver
turn.text: --If a State wishes to adopt such rules, those would... may comply with the fourth amendment.
The question is not, What could be done?
The question is, What was done?

The question is whether California's rule, which permits parolee searches that... with the... absolute prohibition of arbitrary, capricious, and harassing suits, and which must be conducted under the fourth amendment, in terms... reasonable, in terms of time, place, manner, and scope... the question is whether that system, the California scheme, is constitutional under the fourth amendment.
And here, the system was designed to address an overwhelming problem that the Court, this Court, has well defined.
The... over 100,000 parolees are on the street at any given time.
Almost 90,000 of them will be revoked in any given period.
They... the California parolees require intense supervision.
The statute, 3067, was enacted to permit that kind of intense supervision.
And the protection afforded to the parolee, in terms of a requirement of a proper purpose--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Niver.
Mr. Marcus.

turn.speaker: jonathan_l_marcus
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan L. Marcus
turn.text: Thank you.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court--
Concerned about the threat that parolees pose to public safety, the California Legislature, in 1996, authorized both police and parole officers to search them without individualized suspicion.
